panels.description: Busy state of all CPU cores together
panels.title: CPU Busy

panels.description: Non available RAM memory
panels.title: RAM Used

panels.description: Non available disk space
panels.title: Disk Space Used

panels.description: System uptime
panels.title: Uptime

panels.description: Average amount of incoming network traffic over last minute
panels.title: Inbound traffic

panels.description: Number of all Docker contaiers on the system
panels.title: Total containers

panels.description: Number of all running Docker containers
panels.title: Running containers

panels.description: Number of all stopped Docker containers
panels.title: Stopped containers

panels.description: This metric returns 1 if the PostgreSQL instance is up and responding, and 0 if it is down. It serves as a basic health indicator.
panels.title: Database Up

panels.description: Average amount of outgoing network traffic over last minute
panels.title: Outbound traffic

panels.description: The processes consuming the most CPU over the last minute.
panels.title: CPU Usage (top processes)

panels.description: The top 10 processes with the highest RAM usage.
panels.title: RAM usage (top processes)

panels.description: The number of HTTP DELETE requests made for objects in an Amazon S3 bucket. This metric also includes DeleteObjects requests. This metric shows the number of requests made, not the number of objects deleted.
panels.title: All S3 Bucket DELETE Requests

panels.description: The number of HTTP PUT requests made for objects in an Amazon S3 bucket. This metric is incremented for the destination of each CopyObject request.
panels.title: All S3 Bucket PUT Requests

panels.description: The number of bytes uploaded for requests made to an Amazon S3 bucket, where the request includes a body.
panels.title: Uploaded to S3 Bucket

panels.description: The number of HTTP POST requests made to an Amazon S3 bucket. Note: DeleteObjects and SelectObjectContent requests are not included in this metric.
panels.title: All S3 Bucket POST Requests

panels.description: The number of HTTP 4xx client error status code requests made to an Amazon S3 bucket with a value of either 0 or 1. The Average statistic shows the error rate, and the Sum statistic shows the count of that type of error, during each period.
panels.title: Average S3 Bucket 4xx Errors Count

panels.description: The number of HTTP 5xx server error status code requests made to an Amazon S3 bucket with a value of either 0 or 1. The Average statistic shows the error rate, and the Sum statistic shows the count of that type of error, during each period.
panels.title: Average S3 Bucket 5xx Errors Count

panels.description: The per-request time from the complete request being received by an Amazon S3 bucket to when the response starts to be returned.
panels.title: Average S3 Bucket First Byte Latency

panels.description: The elapsed per-request time from the first byte received to the last byte sent to an Amazon S3 bucket. This metric includes the time taken to receive the request body and send the response body, which is not included in FirstByteLatency.
panels.title: Average S3 Bucket Request Latency

panels.description: Busy state of all CPU cores together
panels.title: CPU load

panels.description: Non available RAM memory
panels.title: Occupied RAM

panels.description: Non available disk space
panels.title: Occupied  Disk space

panels.description: Busy state of all CPU cores together (5 min average)
panels.title: Sys Load (5m avg)

panels.description: Busy state of all CPU cores together (15 min average)
panels.title: Sys Load (15m avg)

panels.description: Time (in hours) since each container started.
panels.title: Container Uptime (Days)

panels.description: Number of times each container has been restarted.
panels.title: Container Restarts

panels.description: Displays the percentage of total CPU usage across all cores for each container. Values above 100% indicate usage across multiple cores.
panels.title: Containers' CPU Usage

panels.description: Container memory usage as a percentage (0100).
panels.title: Containers' Memory Usage

panels.description: Rate of bytes read from block devices by each container (bytes/second).
panels.title: Containers' Disk I/O  Read

panels.description: Rate of bytes written to block devices by each container (bytes/second).
panels.title: Containers' Disk I/O  Write

panels.description: Inbound network traffic (bytes/second) per container.
panels.title: Containers' Network RX (Inbound)

panels.description: Outbound network traffic (bytes/second) per container.
panels.title: Containers' Network TX (Outbound)

panels.description: The number of read operations per second. Higher values indicate heavier I/O activity.
panels.title: Reads (IOPS)

panels.description: The number of write operations per second. Higher values indicate heavier I/O activity.
panels.title: Writes (IOPS)

panels.description: The average time that I/O requests spend in the OS queue plus service time. A higher await suggests the disk is taking longer to handle requests, which may indicate contention or slower storage.
panels.title: I/O Await

panels.description: The average service time for I/O requests, excluding queue delays. If service time is high while await is even higher, it suggests significant queuing or waiting in the OS before the device begins servicing requests.
panels.title: I/O Service Time

panels.description: The number of I/O requests currently in flight (the instantaneous queue length). Large spikes can mean multiple I/O operations are queued or being serviced concurrently, potentially causing delays.
panels.title: I/O in Progress (Queue)

panels.description: The percentage of time the disk was busy servicing I/O requests (similar to the %util metric in iostat). A value near 100% implies the disk is fully saturated and may be a bottleneck.
panels.title: Disk Util

panels.description: The rate of how many milliseconds the device has spent servicing I/O. High or steadily increasing values can mean sustained I/O load.
panels.title: I/O Time rate

panels.description: Rate of concurrent operations by multiplying each requests time in flight. Large values indicate multiple requests were being served simultaneously.
panels.title: Weighted I/O Time rate

panels.description: The sum of connections across the delivery, original, and translated databases for each connection state.
panels.title: Connections

panels.description: The rate of committed transactions per second over a 5minute window. It indicates the throughput of the database and how many transactions are being successfully processed.
panels.title: Txn Commits

panels.description: The rate at which transactions are being rolled back per second over a 5minute period. Elevated rollback rates might signal errors in transaction handling or application logic issues.
panels.title: Txn Rollbacks

panels.description: The rate at which disk blocks are read from disk over a 5minute window. It provides insight into the level of disk I/O activity for the PostgreSQL instance.
panels.title: Blocks Read

panels.description: The rate at which PostgreSQL serves disk block requests from its memory cache over a 5minute interval. It is a key input when calculating the cache hit ratio.
panels.title: Blocks Hit

panels.description: The rate of deadlocks (conflicts where two or more transactions are waiting on each other) per second over a 5minute window. Deadlocks can affect performance and may require tuning the database or the application.
panels.title: Deadlocks

panels.description: The rate at which temporary files are created by PostgreSQL per second over a 5minute period. High values can indicate queries that spill over to disk (often due to insufficient memory for sorting or complex joins).
panels.title: Temp Files

panels.description: The percentage of disk block requests served from the PostgreSQL buffer cache. A higher cache hit ratio (closer to 100%) means that most disk requests are being handled in memory, reducing physical disk I/O.
panels.title: Cache Hit Ratio

panels.description: The rate at which bytes are written to temporary files (in bytes per second) over a 5minute window. It provides additional insight into whether queries are using disk as temporary storage.
panels.title: Temp Bytes

panels.description: The total number of HTTP requests that have been observed by UA server.
panels.title: UA server: Total amount of requests

panels.description: The total number of HTTP requests that have been observed by EN server.
panels.title: EN server: Total amount of requests

panels.description: This panel shows the 95th percentile of HTTP request durations computed over a 5minute window. It helps to understand the upper bound of latency experienced by most requests.
panels.title: UA server: HTTP Request Duration (95th Percentile)

panels.description: This panel shows the 95th percentile of HTTP request durations computed over a 5minute window. It helps to understand the upper bound of latency experienced by most requests.
panels.title: EN server: HTTP Request Duration (95th Percentile)

panels.description: The rate of HTTP errors (4xx and 5xx responses) for the API endpoints. It aggregates errors by HTTP method, route, and status code over the last minute.

targets.expr: sum by (app, route, method, status_code) (increase(http_errors_total{status_code=~"^(404|403|500)", app="server-ua.js"}[1m]))

panels.title: UA server: API Error Rate

panels.description: The rate of HTTP errors (4xx and 5xx responses) for the API endpoints. It aggregates errors by HTTP method, route, and status code over the last minute.

targets.expr: sum by (app, route, method, status_code) (increase(http_errors_total{status_code=~"^(404|403|500)", app="server-en.js"}[1m]))

panels.title: EN server: API Error Rate

panels.description: The amount of data in bytes that is stored in a bucket. This value is calculated by summing the size of all objects and metadata (such as bucket names) in the bucket (both current and noncurrent objects), including the size of all parts for all incomplete multipart uploads to the bucket.
panels.title: S3 Bucket Size

panels.description: The total number of objects stored in a general purpose bucket for all storage classes. This value is calculated by counting all objects in the bucket, which includes current and noncurrent objects, delete markers, and the total number of parts for all incomplete multipart uploads to the bucket.
panels.title: Total number of S3 Bucket Objects

panels.description: The number of bytes downloaded for requests made to an Amazon S3 bucket, where the response includes a body.
panels.title: Downloaded from S3 Bucket

panels.description: The number of HTTP GET requests made for objects in an Amazon S3 bucket. This doesn't include list operations. This metric is incremented for the source of each CopyObject request. Note: Paginated list-oriented requests, such as ListMultipartUploads, ListParts, ListObjectVersions, and others, are not included in this metric.
panels.title: All S3 Bucket GET Requests

panels.description: The total number of HTTP requests made to an Amazon S3 bucket, regardless of type.
panels.title: All S3 Bucket Requests

panels.description: The number of HTTP requests that list the contents of a bucket.
panels.title: All S3 Bucket List Requests
